    • After elevating the limb and emptying the veins, a tourniquet is applied at the SFJ and the patient is asked to walk around for a few minutes.
    • If the dilated veins become more prominent, it signifies deep venous obstruction.
  • Three tourniquet test: for specific perforator
  • Fegan’s test for perforator (Option A):
    • On standing, the line of varicosity is marked, and then the veins are emptied in the supine position.
    • The examiner palpates along the marked line and notices any pits or gaps in the deep fascia that signify perforator incompetence at that site.
  • Pratt’s test for perforator: Applying pressure to the calf muscle; if it feels tense and causes pain, it may indicate acute deep vein thrombosis (DVT).
  • Morrisey’s cough impulse test for SFJ incompetence:
    • The patient is asked to turn their face away from the examiner and cough while the examiner keeps a finger at the SFJ, and an expansile cough impulse is felt.
    • Signifies SFJ incompetence.
  • Ian-Aird test for SFJ incompetence.

 

Homan’s test (Option B) is a test for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) rather than venous insufficiency. It involves dorsiflexing the foot and assessing for pain in the calf, which may suggest a clot.

questions.text: All of the following are anterior mediastinal tumors except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lymphoma

Explanation:

  • Lymphoma is a tumor of the middle mediastinum, not the anterior mediastinum.

Tumors of mediastinum

Anterior mediastinum

Middle mediastinum

Posterior mediastinum
  • Thymomas (Option D ruled out)
  • Thymic carcinomas
  • Thymic cyst
  • Germ cell tumors (Option C ruled out)
  • Lymphomas
  • Parathyroid adenomas (Option A ruled out)
  • Carcinoid tumour
  • Fibroma
  • Lymphomas (Option B)
  • Tumors of the heart and great vessels
  • Tumours of the trachea, mainstem bronchi, and oesophagus
  • Aortic pathologies such as aortic aneurysm, abscess, or dissection.
  • Pericardial cysts
  • Bronchogenic cysts
  • Neuroenteric cyst
  • Mesothelial cyst
  • Pheochromocytoma

 
  • Neurilemomas (schwannomas)
  • Neurofibromas
  • Ganglioneuromas
  • Ganglioneuroblastomas
  • Neuroblastomas
  • Pheochromocytomas

questions.text: Which is the least commonly used graft for coronary artery bypass graft (CABG)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Intercostal artery

Explanation:

The intercostal artery is the least commonly used graft in Coronary Artery Bypass Graft (CABG) due to its limited availability and potential complications, with the long saphenous vein, internal mammary artery, and radial artery being preferred options.

  • It is a procedure done by using a vascular graft for bypassing the blocked site of arteries and allowing the flow of blood to the heart muscles.
  • Indications:
    • Triple vessel stenosis
    • Left main stem stenosis
    • Chronic stable angina
    • Angina with persistent chest pain
    • >70% blockage of coronary vessels

Classification of Vascular grafts:

  • Bioprosthetic grafts
    • LIMA (Left Internal Mammary Artery) (Option B ruled out)
    • Long saphenous vein: Most commonly used in infra-inguinal surgeries due to small and medium-sized vessels. (Option A ruled out)
  • Synthetic grafts
    • Dacron: Most commonly used synthetic graft in supra inguinal surgeries due to large vessels.
    • Polyurethane
    • ePTFE (expanded polytetrafluoroethylene)

 

Most preferred graft for CABG is LIMA , but the Long saphenous vein is more commonly used due to its extra length and it is easy to handle.

 

Radial artery (Option D) is a commonly used graft in CABG, offering comparable long-term patency to the internal mammary artery and is particularly useful for smaller coronary arteries. It’s a good alternative to vein grafts, but requires careful harvesting and postoperative monitoring for complications.

questions.text: A 40-year-old smoker presents with sudden, severe, tearing chest pain radiating to his back, shortness of breath, and mild nausea. His BP is 190/110 mmHg, and heart rate is 105 bpm. What is the initial management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Control Blood pressure

Explanation:

  • The case scenario of a smoker presenting with severe, tearing chest pain radiating to his back, shortness of breath, and mild nausea, along with a BP of 190/110 mmHg and heart rate of 105 bpm, is likely experiencing Aortic Dissection, where the initial management focuses on BP control.

It occurs when a defect or a flap occurs in the aorta, resulting in blood tracking into aortic tissues, splitting the medial layer, and creating a false lumen.

Clinical features
  • Sudden onset of severe, tearing chest, radiating to the interscapular region
  • Renal pain and renal failure
  • Paraplegia
  • Syncope
  • Weakness
  • Hypotension or shock

Investigations

  • Stable Patient: CT angiography is the standard investigation of choice.
  • Unstable Patients (SBP<100 mm of HG, HR>100 bpm): TEE (TransEsophageal Echocardiography) (preferred investigation of choice)
  • MRI can also be done if CT is unequivocal.
  • Chest x-ray reveals widening of mediastinum along with left-sided pleural effusion

TEE of an aortic dissection within the descending part

Management

Initial Management: Initial management of all types of aortic dissection includes:

  • Blood pressure control (which is usually high at presentation) (Option A)
  • Strict pain management,
  • Prompt referral for specialist management

Surgical Management

Type A (or type I and II) dissections

Type B (or type III) dissections

Those involving the ascending aorta usually require surgical intervention.

  • Synthetic graft if needed
  • Anastomosis

 

Endovascular stenting of type A dissections.

Initial management:

  • Antihypertensive drugs
  • Monitoring on an acute care unit

 

Complicated cases: If pain worsens, fails to resolve, or malperfusion signs appear (e.g., organ, limb, or neurological symptoms)

  • Percutaneous endovascular stents
  • Surgery (rarely used)

 

Urgent surgery (Option B): Although surgery is often required for aortic dissection, blood pressure control is the initial and most critical step before surgery. Stabilizing the patient with medications like labetalol helps reduce the force on the aorta, preventing further dissection or rupture. Surgery would follow once the patient is stabilized.

Wait and watch (Option C) is not an option for aortic dissection. Aortic dissection is a medical emergency that requires immediate intervention. Delaying treatment with a "wait and watch" approach can lead to life-threatening complications, such as rupture or organ failure.

Blood transfusion (Option D) may be necessary if there is significant blood loss, but it is not the first line of management for aortic dissection. The priority is stabilizing the patient with blood pressure control to minimize the risk of further dissection or rupture before considering other interventions like a transfusion.

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic man presents with a progressive increase in pain in his calf. He now prefers to sleep in a seated position by hanging his leg to alleviate pain.Pain is more in the distal part like toes and feet. It gets aggravated with movements and pressure. The pain is increased in lying down and elevation of foot; it may be reduced on hanging the foot down. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct option :

  • Option a: The most likely cause of the patient's symptoms, based on the provided information, is rest pain. 
  • Rest pain

  • It is continuous aching in calf or feet and toes or in the region even at rest depending on site of obstruction.

  • It is a ‘cry of dying nerves’ due to ischemia of the somatic nerves. It signifies severe decompensated ischemia.

  • Pain gets aggravated by elevation and is relieved in dependent position of the limb

  • Pain is more in the distal part like toes and feet. It gets aggravated with movements and pressure.

  • Rest pain is increased in lying down and elevation of foot; it may be reduced on hanging the foot down.

Incorrect Choices: 

  • Option b: Sciatica is a condition that causes pain, numbness, or weakness in the lower back, buttocks, and legs due to compression or irritation of the sciatic nerve. However, the patient's symptoms of worsening pain with walking and relief by hanging the leg are inconsistent with sciatica.
  • Option c: Neurogenic claudication is another possible cause of the patient's symptoms, which occurs due to spinal stenosis or nerve root compression, causing pain, numbness, and weakness in the lower back, buttocks, and legs. However, the patient's symptoms of worsening pain with walking and relief by hanging the leg are not typical of neurogenic claudication.
  • Option d: Venous claudication is caused by chronic venous insufficiency, leading to decreased blood flow and oxygen supply to the affected tissues. However, the patient's symptoms of worsening pain with walking and relief by hanging the leg are not typical of venous claudication.

questions.text: What is the most preferred site for the insertion of the intercostal tube drain?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Upper border of lower rib 

  • The upper border of lower rib is the most preferred site because it helps to avoid injury to important structures like the neurovascular bundle that runs along the lower border of the rib.
  • By inserting the needle just above the upper border of the lower rib, there's a decreased risk of damaging these structures.

Incorrect options: Option B, C and D are not the preferred sites for the insertion of intercostal tube drain.

questions.text: A 17-year-old woman with no comorbidities presents with numbness and paraesthesia of the fingers along with the characteristic finding as shown in the image below. She has no history of smoking or history of other illnesses. She mentions the episodes occur when she is under excess stress or during cold temperatures. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Raynaud’s phenomenon

Explanation:

  • The scenario of a young woman experiencing numbness, paresthesia, and bluish discoloration of the fingers during cold stress or excessive stress, with no comorbidities, smoking history, or other illnesses, is most likely diagnosed as Raynaud's Phenomenon.

Category

Description

Definition

It is characterized by episodic reduction in blood flow, typically in the fingers, triggered by cold exposure or stress.

Clinical Features
  • Pallor: Skin becomes pale or white due to reduced blood flow.
  • Cyanosis: Skin turns blue or purple due to deoxygenation of blood.
  • Rubor: Skin turns red as blood flow returns, often with swelling and tingling.
  • Cold Sensitivity: Cold, numb fingers.
  • Pain: Pain during the cyanotic phase.
  • Swelling and Tingling: Occurs in the rubor phase.

Types
  • Primary Raynaud Phenomenon (Raynaud Disease):
    • Occurs without underlying disease.
    • More common and has a better prognosis.
  • Secondary Raynaud Phenomenon (Raynaud Syndrome):
    • Occurs due to an underlying condition (e.g., scleroderma, lupus).
    • Often more severe.

Management
  • Lifestyle Modifications: Avoid cold exposure, stress reduction, and smoking cessation.
  • Medications: Calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine), alpha-blockers (e.g., prazosin), and other vasodilators.
  • Avoidance of Triggers: Avoid cold, beta-blockers, and caffeine.
  • Advanced Treatments: Surgical sympathectomy for severe cases.

Diagnosis
  • Clinical Presentation and History: Based on symptoms and triggers.
  • Nailfold Capillaroscopy: To examine capillary changes.
  • Blood Tests: To identify underlying autoimmune or connective tissue diseases.

Sequence of events in Raynaud’s phenomenon:

  • Pallor: The initial phase where the skin becomes pale or white due to reduced blood flow and vasospasm.
  • Cyanosis: Followed by a blue or purple colour due to continued reduced blood flow and lack of oxygen.
  • Rubor: The final phase is where the skin turns red as blood flow returns and the area warms up.

 

Buerger’s disease (thromboangiitis obliterans) (Option A) is an inflammatory condition affecting small and medium-sized arteries and veins, leading to clot formation and reduced blood flow. It is most commonly seen in young male smokers and is characterized by painful ischemia, ulceration, or gangrene of the fingers or toes. This diagnosis is unlikely due to the absence of smoking history, risk factors, and ulcerative symptoms.

 

Atherosclerosis (Option B) is the buildup of fatty plaques in arteries, often seen in older individuals with risk factors like smoking, high cholesterol, hypertension, and diabetes. This diagnosis is unlikely for the young woman, as she has no comorbidities or risk factors, and atherosclerosis typically presents with chronic symptoms such as pain or claudication, rather than intermittent symptoms triggered by cold or stress.

Giant cell arteritis (GCA) (Option D) affects large arteries in people over 50, causing headaches, scalp tenderness, jaw claudication, and vision issues.

questions.text: A patient with varicose veins complains of eczema in the same region. According to the CEAP guidelines, what is the stage of the clinical classification?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) C4a

Explanation:

  • According to the CEAP (Clinical, Etiological, Anatomical, and Pathophysiological) classification system for chronic venous disease, C4a refers to skin changes such as eczema or pigmentation in the presence of varicose veins.

The CEAP (Clinical- Etiology- Anatomy- Pathology) classification for chronic venous disorders:

Clinical Classification (C):

Class Description
C0 No visible or palpable signs of venous disease
C1 Telangiectasia or reticular veins (<1–3 mm)
C2 Varicose veins (>3 mm)
C3 Edema without skin changes
C4a Pigmentation or eczema
C4b Lipodermatosclerosis (LDS) or atrophie blanche
C4c Corona phlebectatica
C5 Healed venous ulcer
C6 Active venous ulcer

Each class can be followed by a modifier:

  • a = Asymptomatic

  • s = Symptomatic

  • r = Recurrent (after successful treatment/healing)
    Example: C2s, C6r

Etiological Classification (E)

Code Description
Ec Congenital
Ep Primary
Es Secondary (e.g., post-thrombotic)
En No venous etiology identified

 

Anatomical Classification (A)

Code Description
As Superficial veins
Ap Perforator veins
Ad Deep veins
An No venous location identified

 

Pathophysiological Classification (P)

Code Description
Pr Reflux
Po Obstruction
Pr,o Reflux and obstruction
Pn No identifiable pathology

Pigmentation/Eczema LDS

 

Atrophic blanche Corona phlebectatica

questions.text: Identify the given condition:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Trophic ulcer

Explanation:

  • Trophic ulcers, also called neuropathic ulcers, occur due to a loss of sensation and an impaired ability to protect the skin, often resulting from conditions like peripheral neuropathy or poor circulation. These ulcers usually have well-defined borders and a pale or pink wound bed, commonly located in weight-bearing areas where pressure or friction is frequent.

Type of Ulcer:

Type

History

Lesion Characteristics

Pain

Ischemic/Arterial

Smoking, intermittent claudication

Irregular edges, poor granulation tissue, dry necrotic base; round or punched-out with sharp demarcation

Severe, particularly at night; relieved by dependency

Venous

Varicose veins, DVT, trauma, surgery, multiple pregnancies

Shallow, irregular/shaggy shape, granulating base, fibrinous material with moderate to heavy exudate

Mild; relieved by elevation

Neurotrophic

Numbness, paresthesias, burning, loss of sensation in the foot, DM

Punched-out, deep sinus, variable depth, partial thickness to severe, involving the tendon, fascia, joint capsule, or bone

None

Malignant Ulcer

History of skin cancer (e.g., basal or squamous cell carcinoma)

Irregular, raised borders, ulcerating tumour with hard, indurated tissue

Often painful, it can be associated with bleeding or foul odour

questions.text: A construction worker presents to the OPD with complaints of white fingers. He has been working in the cement and concrete industry and has spent 20 years using heavy machinery drills and polishing wood and furniture. What is the most likely etiology for this condition?

choices.text: Candidal infection of the fingers due to continuous exposure to water
Continuous exposure to cement and concrete
Continuous exposure to drills and machines

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Continuous exposure to drills and machines

Explanation:

  • The patient's symptoms of white fingers are suggestive of the vibration-induced white finger (VWF) or hand-arm vibration syndrome (HAVS), a secondary form of Raynaud syndrome, which is caused by prolonged exposure to vibrating tools and machinery.
  • This condition leads to reduced blood flow and ischemia in the fingers, resulting in the characteristic whiteness of the fingers.

Raynaud’s Syndrome: Raynaud’s syndrome is the peripheral arterial manifestation of a collagen vascular disease, such as systemic lupus erythematosus or rheumatoid arthritis. It shares clinical features with Raynaud’s disease but is often more severe.

  • It can also occur due to vibrating tool use, a recognised industrial disease known as vibration white finger.
  • Clinical features:
    • The symptoms are similar to Raynaud’s disease but can be more aggressive.
    • In secondary Raynaud’s syndrome (due to collagen diseases), there may be necrosis of digits and multiple amputations.
  • Management:
    • Primary treatment focuses on addressing the underlying condition.
    • Conservative measures can be helpful, including:
      • Nifedipine
      • Steroids
      • Vasospastic antagonists
    • Sympathectomy generally provides poor outcomes and is not recommended.
  • Prevention: Patients with a vibrated white finger should avoid vibrating tools to prevent further damage.

questions.text: A patient presents with a sudden onset of chest pain shooting to the neck and interscapular region. X-ray shows a widened mediastinum. Blood pressure is 110/90 mmHg in the right upper limb and 160/100 mmHg in the left upper limb. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Acute aortic dissection

Explanation:

  • Acute aortic dissection often presents with sudden, severe chest pain radiating to the neck and interscapular region. A widened mediastinum on X-ray is a classic sign. The significant difference in blood pressure between the right and left upper limbs suggests aortic dissection, as it can cause unequal blood flow due to dissection of the aortic wall.

Aortic Dissection: Occurs when a defect or a flap occurs in the aorta, resulting in blood tracking into aortic tissues, splitting the medial layer, and creating a false lumen.

 

Clinical features:

  • Sudden onset of severe, tearing chest, radiating to the interscapular region
  • Renal pain and renal failure
  • Paraplegia
  • Syncope
  • Weakness
  • Hypotension or shock

Investigations:

  • If the patient is stable, CT angiography is the standard investigation of choice.
  • In the case of unstable patients (SBP<100 mm of HG, HR>100 bpm), the preferred investigation of choice will be TEE (TransEsophageal Echocardiography)(Option C)
  • MRI can also be done if CT is unequivocal.
  • Chest x-ray reveals widening of mediastinum along with left-sided pleural effusion.

TEE of an aortic dissection within the descending part

DeBakey Classification

(Based on the pattern of dissection)

Type I

Both ascending and descending aorta are involved

Type II

Only the ascending aorta is involved

Type III

Only the descending aorta is involved

Stanford Classification

(Based on whether the ascending aorta is involved in aortic dissection)

Type A

 

Only the ascending aorta or both ascending and descending aorta is involved.

(It includes both Type I and Type II of DeBakey’s classification)

Type B

 

Only the descending aorta is involved.

(It includes Type III of DeBakey’s classification)

 

Acute coronary syndrome (Option A): This condition usually presents with central chest pain radiating to the left arm or jaw, often accompanied by sweating, nausea, and shortness of breath. The difference in blood pressure between the arms is not a characteristic feature of acute coronary syndrome.

Acute pulmonary embolism (Option B) typically presents with sudden onset dyspnea, chest pain, and possibly hemoptysis. While an ECG might show signs of right heart strain or sinus tachycardia, it does not cause a discrepancy in blood pressure between the limbs.

Esophageal rupture (Option D) often occurs after severe vomiting (e.g., Boerhaave's syndrome) and presents with severe chest pain. The X-ray would typically show mediastinal air rather than a widened mediastinum.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient presents with pain in the calf muscles while walking. The pain subsides with rest. Which of the following is not typically seen in intermittent claudication?

choices.text: Cramping in the muscles during exercise
Pain starting on taking the first step
The most common cause is atheroma
The level of occlusion cannot be decided based on symptoms

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pain starting on taking the first step

Explanation:

  • Intermittent claudication typically involves cramping pain in the calf muscles during exercise (such as walking), which subsides with rest. The pain usually starts after walking for a certain distance and is relieved by rest, not immediately upon taking the first step.

 

Boyd's classification of intermittent claudication:

Grade

Description

Grade 0: Asymptomatic

No symptoms of claudication, even with exercise

Grade I: Mild claudication

Able to walk more than 200 meters (about 650 feet) before onset of symptoms

Grade II: Moderate claudication

Able to walk between 50 and 200 meters (about 160 to 650 feet) before onset of symptoms

Grade III: Severe claudication

Able to walk less than 50 meters (about 160 feet) before onset of symptoms

Grade IV: Ischemic rest pain

Pain occurs at rest or with minimal exertion

 

Incorrect Options:

Cramping in the muscles during exercise (Option A): Intermittent claudication is characterised by pain or cramping in the muscles during exercise, usually affecting the lower extremities.

The most common cause is atheroma (Option C): Atheroma, which is the accumulation of fatty plaques in the arteries, is the primary cause of intermittent claudication. The narrowing of the arteries due to atheroma restricts blood flow to the muscles during physical activity, resulting in pain.

Level of occlusion cannot be decided based on symptoms (Option D): The exact level of arterial occlusion cannot be determined by symptoms alone in intermittent claudication. Diagnostic tests, such as ankle-brachial index (ABI) or angiography, are needed to assess the location and extent of arterial blockage.

ABI/ABPI: ABPI (Ankle brachial pressure index) is measured supine by checking the systolic blood pressure in both upper and lower limbs (brachial, posterior tibial, and dorsalis pedis arteries). The higher value from each limb is used to calculate the ABPI. 

  • This index is calculated as:

ABI / ABPI = Systolic BP in the Ankle/ Systolic BP in the arm
  • Interpretations are as follows:

Value

Interpretation

0.1 - 0.4

Critical limb ischemia

0.5 - 0.9

Intermittent claudication

1.0 - 1.2

Normal

> 1.2

Calcified vessels (seen in patients with DM, End stage renal disease)

questions.text: Which of the following provides long-lasting results in a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Internal mammary artery:

  • The internal mammary artery is the vessel that provides long-lasting results in a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG).

  • Coronary artery bypass grafting is a surgical procedure that is used to improve blood flow to the heart muscle by bypassing blocked or narrowed coronary arteries. During the procedure, a healthy blood vessel from another part of the body is grafted onto the blocked or narrowed artery, creating a new route for blood to flow to the heart.

  • The internal mammary artery is located inside the chest, and it supplies blood to the chest wall and the heart muscle. It is an ideal vessel for CABG because it is resistant to the development of atherosclerosis (a buildup of plaque inside the artery), which can lead to re-narrowing or blockage of the grafted vessel over time.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Long saphenous vein: The long saphenous vein is often used in CABG procedures, may develop atherosclerosis and become blocked over time, leading to the need for repeat surgeries. 

Option C - Poly tetra fluoro eythlene (PTFE): PTFE is a synthetic material that can be used in CABG, but it may also develop atherosclerosis over time. 

Option D - Gastroepiploic artery: The gastroepiploic artery is another option, but it is not as commonly used as the internal mammary artery.

questions.text: The given below device is :
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pneumatic compression stocking:

  • Pneumatic compression stockings, also known as intermittent pneumatic compression (IPC) devices or sequential compression devices (SCDs), are commonly used as a prophylactic measure to prevent deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in various clinical settings. 

  • Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is the formation of a blood clot in the deep veins of the body, usually in the legs. It can be a serious condition that may lead to complications such as pulmonary embolism if the blood clot dislodges and travels to the lungs.

  • Pneumatic compression stockings are designed to improve blood flow in the legs and reduce the risk of blood clot formation. These stockings are made of inflatable chambers or sleeves that are connected to a device that periodically inflates and deflates the chambers.

  • When the pneumatic compression stockings are worn, the chambers sequentially inflate, applying gentle pressure to the legs in a specific pattern. This pressure helps to promote blood flow in the veins by compressing the superficial veins, thereby reducing venous stasis (slow blood flow) and enhancing venous return (blood flow back to the heart).

  • The sequential inflation and deflation of the chambers create a pumping effect, mimicking the natural movement of the muscles during walking or exercising. This action helps prevent blood from pooling or stagnating in the veins, reducing the likelihood of blood clot formation.

  • Pneumatic compression stockings are often used in situations where individuals are at an increased risk of developing DVT, such as during surgery, prolonged bed rest, or when mobility is limited. They are also utilized for individuals with certain medical conditions or predisposing factors for DVT.

  • It's important to note that pneumatic compression stockings are just one aspect of DVT prevention and are often used in conjunction with other preventive measures. These may include early mobilization, regular leg exercises, pharmacological prophylaxis (such as anticoagulant medications), and maintaining adequate hydration.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Elastic Compression Stockings: The image given above is of Pneumatic compression stockings. 

Option C - Vacuum assisted closure devices: They are used for wound closure and stress ulcers

Option D - Cellulites: Cellulitis is a bacterial skin infection characterized by redness, swelling, and tenderness, not shown in the image.

questions.text: What are the distinguishing features between cardiac tamponade and tension pneumothorax?

choices.text: Not improving after initial fluid resuscitation

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Breath sounds:

  • Assessing breath sounds can help differentiate between cardiac tamponade and tension pneumothorax. In cardiac tamponade, breath sounds are typically normal because the primary issue is compression of the heart. In tension pneumothorax, on the other hand, there may be absent or decreased breath sounds on the affected side due to lung collapse.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Raised JVP (Jugular Venous Pressure): Both cardiac tamponade and tension pneumothorax can result in an elevated JVP. However, this is not a specific finding that can differentiate between the two conditions.

Option C - Raised heart rate: Both cardiac tamponade and tension pneumothorax can lead to an increased heart rate. It is a non-specific finding and cannot be used to differentiate between the two conditions.

Option D - Not improving after initial fluid resuscitation: This option is not specific to either cardiac tamponade or tension pneumothorax. It is more indicative of a lack of response to initial fluid resuscitation and can occur in various conditions.

questions.text: While washing clothes in cold water, a female patient exhibits color changes in her hands from white to red. Which of the following drugs is best suited for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Calcium channel blockers:

  • The symptoms described in the question suggest that the patient is experiencing Raynaud's phenomenon.

  •  In this condition, the blood vessels in the fingers and toes spasm and temporarily restrict blood flow. 

  • This can cause the affected areas to turn white, blue, and red. 

  • Cold temperatures or emotional stress can trigger the spasms.

  • The best-suited drug for this patient would be a calcium channel blocker. 

  • These drugs work by relaxing the smooth muscle in the blood vessel walls, which can help to prevent or reduce the frequency of vasospasms.

  • Calcium channel blockers are often used as first-line therapy for Raynaud's phenomenon.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - ACE inhibitors: ACE inhibitors are a type of blood pressure medication that works by blocking the production of angiotensin II, a hormone that can constrict blood vessels. However, they are ineffective in treating vasospastic disorders like Raynaud's phenomenon. 

Option C - Thiazides: Thiazides are a type of diuretic used to treat high blood pressure and edema, but they do not affect the blood vessels in a way that would be useful for treating Raynaud's phenomenon. 

Option D - Alpha-blockers: Alpha-blockers are another type of blood pressure medication that blocks the alpha receptors on blood vessel walls, causing them to relax and dilate. However, alpha-blockers are ineffective in treating Raynaud's phenomenon because they do not target the underlying vasospasms.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to the ER with severe chest pain. On examination, BP 200/100 mmHg, and HR 120/min. CTA confirms Stanford type A aortic dissection. What is the initial management step?

choices.text: Start esmolol followed by sodium nitroprusside
Start sodium nitroprusside followed by esmolol

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Start esmolol followed by sodium nitroprusside

  • Note that question is on initial management and not definite management.
  • Initial Management Principles:
    • Goal: Reduce heart rate and blood pressure to decrease the force of left ventricular ejection (dP/dt), thus minimizing extension of the dissection.
    • Step 1: Beta-blocker first (e.g., esmolol)
      • Lowers heart rate (target HR <60 bpm)
      • Reduces contractility and shear stress
    • Step 2: Vasodilator (e.g., sodium nitroprusside)
      • Used only after beta-blockade is established
      • Lowers systolic BP (target <120 mmHg)
      • If used before beta-blockade, can cause reflex tachycardia, which worsens dissection.
  • In Stanford type A aortic dissection, Option A is correct because beta-blockers reduce heart rate and shear stress, and vasodilators are added after to control BP. After medical stabilization surgical repair will have a better prognosis intra and postoperatively.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Start sodium nitroprusside followed by esmolol: It is incorrect as giving nitroprusside first can cause reflex tachycardia, worsening the dissection.

Option C -  Immediate surgical repair - It is essential but only after stabilization with BP and HR control.

Option D - Administer vitamin K inhibitors - They are anticoagulants and contraindicated, as they increase bleeding risk. Thus, medical stabilization with beta-blocker first is the initial lifesaving step.

questions.text: An abdominal aortic aneurysm is operated when its size is greater than____?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 5.5 cm: 

  • This is the commonly accepted size threshold for elective surgical repair of an AAA. Once an aneurysm reaches or exceeds this size, the risk of rupture significantly increases, and the potential benefits of surgical intervention to prevent rupture outweigh the risks associated with the procedure.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 5 cm: This is below the generally accepted size threshold for surgical intervention. AAA measuring less than 5 cm in diameter are often monitored through regular imaging studies to detect any significant growth.

Option B - 6 cm: While an AAA measuring 6 cm in diameter is larger and carries a higher risk of rupture, the threshold for elective repair is typically set at 5.5 cm. 

Option D - 6.5 cm: An AAA measuring 6.5 cm is considered a large aneurysm that poses a high risk of rupture.

questions.text: What is the most frequently encountered tumor in the mediastinum?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Neurogenic tumors:

  • Most common posterior mediastinal mass  and also overall  most common mediastinal mass are neurogenic tumors

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Thymoma: Thymoma is a tumor that originates from the thymus gland, which is located in the mediastinum. They are the most common anterior mediastinal mass

Option C - Lymphoma: Lymphomas are cancers that originate from lymphocytes, a type of white blood cell. While lymphomas can involve the mediastinum, they are not as common as thymomas.

Option D - Bronchial cyst: Bronchial cysts are abnormal fluid-filled sacs that develop within the bronchial walls. While they can occur in the mediastinum, they are not the most common mediastinal tumors.

questions.text: Identify the lesion shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Wet gangrene: 

  • Wet gangrene is a type of gangrene characterized by tissue necrosis (death) that occurs in a moist or wet environment. It is usually caused by a severe bacterial infection and impaired blood supply to the affected area. The affected tissue appears swollen, discolored (often dark or black), and may have a foul odor. It is commonly seen in the extremities, such as the feet.

  • In the given image, the appearance of the foot with discoloration, swelling, and signs of tissue decay suggests the presence of wet gangrene. The presence of a severe infection and impaired blood supply are consistent with this diagnosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Dry gangrene: Dry gangrene is characterized by tissue death in a dry environment without the presence of infection. It usually occurs due to reduced blood supply to the affected area, leading to tissue necrosis. Dry gangrene often appears black, dry, and shriveled.

Option C - Frostbite: Frostbite refers to tissue injury caused by extreme cold exposure. It occurs when prolonged exposure to freezing temperatures leads to damage to the skin and underlying tissues. Frostbite can cause discoloration, numbness, and blistering of the affected area.

Option D - Ainhum: Ainhum is a rare condition characterized by the progressive constriction and autoamputation of the digits, usually the fifth toe. It typically affects individuals in certain geographical regions and is associated with the formation of a fibrous band around the affected digit.

questions.text: What is the most frequently observed complication in a 29-year-old man who visits the outpatient department due to pain, heaviness, and swelling in his right leg? The patient has been dealing with varicose veins since he was 12 years old. After undergoing below-knee stripping of the long saphenous vein, both the symptoms and visible varicose veins disappeared.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Neuralgia:

  • Neuralgia refers to the condition characterized by sharp, shooting, or burning pain along the course of a nerve. In the context of the patient's history of varicose veins and subsequent surgical intervention (below-knee stripping of the long saphenous vein), neuralgia can occur as a common complication. This can happen due to nerve damage during the surgical procedure or as a result of ongoing irritation or inflammation of the nerves in the affected area.

Incorrect Options:

Options A - Hemorrhage: Hemorrhage, or excessive bleeding, is a potential complication of any surgical procedure. However, in the given scenario, where the patient's symptoms resolved completely after the surgery, hemorrhage is less likely to be the most common complication.

Options B - Thromboembolism: Thromboembolism refers to the formation of a blood clot (thrombus) that travels through the bloodstream and blocks a blood vessel. While varicose veins can increase the risk of blood clots, the patient's symptoms improved after the surgery, suggesting that thromboembolism is not the most common complication in this case.

Options D - Infection: Infection is a possible complication of any surgical procedure. However, the patient's symptoms resolved after the surgery, making infection less likely to be the most common complication.

questions.text: Which of the following are indications for surgical intervention in abdominal aortic aneurysms?

choices.text: Size more than 5.5 cm in males
Size more than 5 cm in females

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - All the above:

  • All of the above are indications for surgical intervention in abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAAs).

Option A - Size more than 5.5 cm in males: This criterion is based on the risk of rupture. An AAA larger than 5.5 cm in diameter has a higher risk of rupture, and surgical intervention is recommended to prevent rupture and its potentially life-threatening consequences.

Option B - Size more than 5 cm in females: Although the threshold for surgical intervention is slightly lower in females compared to males, an AAA larger than 5 cm in diameter is still considered an indication for surgery in females. This is because females generally have a smaller aorta, and smaller aneurysms in women may carry a higher risk of rupture compared to men.

Option C - Expansion of > 0.5 cm within 6 months: Rapid expansion of an AAA indicates an increased risk of rupture. If the aneurysm grows more than 0.5 cm within a 6-month period, surgical intervention is recommended to prevent rupture.

questions.text: Which complication is seen after the Varicose vein stripping procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Neuralgia: 

  • Varicose vein stripping is a surgical procedure used to remove varicose veins, which are enlarged and twisted veins usually found in the legs.

  • While varicose vein stripping is generally safe, complications can occur. One of the complications associated with this procedure is neuralgia, which refers to nerve pain or nerve damage.

  • Neuralgia can manifest as persistent or intermittent pain along the distribution of the affected nerves.

Incorrect Options:

Options B - Deep vein thrombosis: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a condition characterized by the formation of blood clots in the deep veins, typically in the legs. While DVT is a possible complication of varicose veins themselves, it is not directly associated with the varicose vein stripping procedure.

Options C - Acrocyanosis: Acrocyanosis is a condition characterized by persistent bluish discoloration of the hands and feet, usually due to reduced blood flow to the peripheral vessels. It is not a direct complication of varicose vein stripping.

Options D - Telangiectasia: Telangiectasia refers to the dilation of small blood vessels near the surface of the skin, resulting in the appearance of fine red or purple lines. While telangiectasia may be associated with varicose veins, it is not a specific complication of the varicose vein stripping procedure.

questions.text: Which is the most common anterior mediastinal tumour?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Thymoma:

  • Thymoma is the most common anterior mediastinal tumor.
  • It arises from the thymus gland and is typically slow-growing.
  • Thymomas can be associated with autoimmune disorders and myasthenia gravis.

Incorrect Options:

Options B - Neurofibroma:

  • Neurofibromas are benign tumors that arise from nerve tissue.
  • They are more commonly found in peripheral nerves.

Option C - Pericardial cyst:

  • Pericardial cysts are fluid-filled sacs that develop in the pericardium, the sac surrounding the heart.

Option D - Bronchogenic cyst:

  • Bronchogenic cysts are congenital abnormalities that arise from abnormal development of the lung bud during embryogenesis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic smoker presents with pain in his right leg. Upon examination, the pulse in the bilateral popliteal fossa is absent, and he experiences pain in the both buttock . Which level block is most likely present?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Aortoiliac Artery:

  • The patient's symptoms, including absent pulses in the bilateral popliteal fossa and pain in both buttocks, are indicative of aortoiliac artery disease.

  • Aortoiliac artery disease commonly presents with buttock, thigh, and calf claudication, which is pain or cramping in the muscles of the lower extremities during physical activity.

  • This condition is often associated with atherosclerosis, especially in chronic smokers like the patient described.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Femoral Artery Disease:

  • Common femoral artery disease typically presents with thigh and calf claudication, rather than pain in the buttocks.

  • In this condition, the patient may experience pain or cramping in the muscles of the thigh and calf during physical activity due to inadequate blood supply.

Option C - Popliteal Artery Disease:

  • Popliteal artery disease usually manifests as calf claudication, not pain in the buttocks.

  • Patients with popliteal artery disease may experience pain or cramping in the calf muscles during physical activity due to reduced blood flow to the lower leg.

Option D - Iliac Artery Disease:

  • While iliac artery disease can cause symptoms similar to aortoiliac artery disease, such as buttock, thigh, and calf claudication, the absent pulses in the bilateral popliteal fossa are not characteristic of isolated iliac artery disease.

questions.text: The most commonly involved artery in pseudoaneurysm formation:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Femoral artery:

  • The femoral artery is a common location for pseudoaneurysm formation. It is a large artery located in the groin area and is frequently accessed for arterial catheterization or invasive procedures such as angiography, cardiac catheterization, or arterial line placement. Pseudoaneurysms can occur as a complication of these procedures due to the puncture and subsequent incomplete closure of the artery, leading to the formation of a pulsating hematoma.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Aorta: While the aorta can develop aneurysms, a pseudoaneurysm, also known as a false aneurysm, is less commonly associated with the aorta. 

Option C - Popliteal artery: The popliteal artery is located behind the knee and is also susceptible to pseudoaneurysm formation. However, compared to the femoral artery, pseudoaneurysms in the popliteal artery are less common. Popliteal artery pseudoaneurysms can occur due to trauma, iatrogenic injury, or underlying vascular diseases affecting the artery.

Option D - None of the above: This option is incorrect as both the femoral artery (Option B) and the popliteal artery (Option C) can be involved in pseudoaneurysm formation, with the femoral artery being the more commonly involved artery.

questions.text: On the 5th postoperative day post CABG, the patient develops tachypnea and hypotension. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Acute respiratory failure:

  • Acute respiratory failure refers to a condition in which the lungs fail to provide adequate oxygenation to the body or efficiently remove carbon dioxide. Tachypnea (rapid breathing) and hypotension can be signs of inadequate oxygenation and perfusion. After CABG, potential causes of acute respiratory failure can include atelectasis (collapsed lung), pneumonia, pulmonary embolism, or other complications affecting lung function. Prompt evaluation and intervention are crucial to address respiratory compromise.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Sepsis: Sepsis is a severe systemic infection that can cause various symptoms, including tachypnea and hypotension. However, without additional information, it is less likely to be the most probable cause on the 5th postoperative day after CABG. Other signs such as fever, elevated white blood cell count, or evidence of infection would be important to consider for a definitive diagnosis of sepsis.

Option B - Acute kidney failure: Acute kidney failure, also known as acute renal failure, primarily affects kidney function and may manifest as decreased urine output, fluid overload, electrolyte disturbances, or changes in laboratory parameters such as elevated creatinine levels. While it can cause hypotension, tachypnea is not a typical symptom of acute kidney failure. Therefore, it is less likely to be the most probable cause in this scenario.

Option D - Acute cardiac failure: Acute cardiac failure, also known as acute heart failure or congestive heart failure, typically presents with symptoms such as shortness of breath, fatigue, fluid retention, and signs of poor cardiac output. While acute cardiac failure can cause hypotension, tachypnea alone is less commonly associated with this condition. Other cardiac symptoms, such as edema, jugular venous distention, or abnormal heart sounds, would be important to consider for a definitive diagnosis of acute cardiac failure.
